ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mostly I think this course taught me synthesis -- how to integrate systems and how to integrate interests and ideas and opinions. I'm not sure I actually learned anything new in EE, but it was the first real project I was a part of and so there is a lot of practical stuff that goes into that that you pick up through the semester. Developing your own goals and ideas, communicating the steps you need to take, and understanding your expectations for the group and the group's expectations of you.
I got a better understand of robots, autonomous operation, and teleoperation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was an extraordinarily challenging thing to be doing in the pandemic because we spent most of the semester working individually, apart, unclear of what the robot actually was, how it operated, and most importantly what each person in the group was really doing. Prof. Kuc also took a very long time to share materials with us or really communicate with us what the robot was already capable of and how it operated and also what the real end goal was. When those things finally became apparent to us, we only had a month left and it was a scramble to get things done and working. I think being able to access all the code, documentation, photos, etc. right away at the start of the semester would have made all of our lives easier. In a year when we would be meeting in person and able to work side by side much of our issues would be non-issues.

I feel like there wasn't enough space for students to take initiative to complete the project goal.  We did a lot at the beginning of the semester that delayed the project with very little to no benefit towards the final goals.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that the course was adapted well for the situation.  However, the virtual nature made it very challenging for teamwork.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend it for EE majors.
Yes! ABET is a great degree and this is an excellent capstone project course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We have weekly zoom meetings and have recently started meeting in person in our lab space to implement our project physically.
We had virtual lecture, but our project was conducted in-person.
